abstract: Adds a value and its label to a multivalue list.

declaration.code: func add(_ value: Any!, withLabel label: String!) -> String!

overview:
## Return Value

The new identifier if `value` is added successfully; otherwise, `nil`.

## Discussion

The `value` argument must be of the correct type. For example, if the receiver is the value for a property of type `kABMultiStringProperty`, then `value` needs to be an NSString object. See [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/property_types] for a list of supported types in a multivalue list (see descriptions of the `kABMulti...` constants). If either the `value` or the `label` argument is `nil`, this method raises an exception.

This method performs no type checking and will let you add a value whose type does not match the types of the other values in the list. However, if you try to use a multivalue list whose values are not all of the same type, other methods, such as the `ABRecord`  [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/ABRecord-swift.class/setValue(_:forProperty:)] method, will return `false` or [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/kABErrorInProperty].

# add(_:withLabel:)

**Instance Method**

Adds a value and its label to a multivalue list.

## Declaration

```swift
func add(_ value: Any!, withLabel label: String!) -> String!
```

## Parameters

- **value**: The value to add.
- **label**: The label to associate with the value.

## Return Value

The new identifier if `value` is added successfully; otherwise, `nil`.

## Discussion

The `value` argument must be of the correct type. For example, if the receiver is the value for a property of type `kABMultiStringProperty`, then `value` needs to be an NSString object. See [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/property_types] for a list of supported types in a multivalue list (see descriptions of the `kABMulti...` constants). If either the `value` or the `label` argument is `nil`, this method raises an exception.

This method performs no type checking and will let you add a value whose type does not match the types of the other values in the list. However, if you try to use a multivalue list whose values are not all of the same type, other methods, such as the `ABRecord`  [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/ABRecord-swift.class/setValue(_:forProperty:)] method, will return `false` or [doc://com.apple.addressbook/documentation/AddressBook/kABErrorInProperty].

## Adding a value

- **insert(_:withLabel:at:)**: Inserts a value and its label at the given index in a multivalue list.
